Introduction

Hordeolum, also known as a stye, is a localized infection or inflammation of the eyelid glands.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Hordeolum typically arises from the infection of the eyelid glands, particularly the meibomian glands (external hordeolum) or the Zeis glands (internal hordeolum) (

image 1
).  Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent causative organism.  The inflammation and obstruction of the glandular ducts leads to the accumulation of secretions, resulting in the formation of a painful, erythematous nodule on the eyelid.



Risk factors include poor eyelid hygiene, chronic blepharitis (inflammation of the eyelid margin), and skin conditions such as rosacea, seborrheic dermatitis, or acne vulgaris.

Clinical presentation



Patients with a hordeolum typically present with a localized, painful swelling on the eyelid; the affected area is often red, swollen, and tender to palpation.  An external hordeolum (stye) typically presents as a pustule or abscess at the base of an eyelash follicle, whereas an internal hordeolum may manifest as a deeper, more diffuse swelling within the eyelid.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of hordeolum is primarily clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of a painful, erythematous eyelid nodule.  Differentiation between external and internal hordeolum may be determined based on the location of the lesion and the presence of a visible pustule; however, distinguishing between them does not affect management.

Differential diagnosis



  • Chalazion (meibomian cyst) (
    image 2
    ):  A painless, chronic granulomatous inflammation of the eyelid resulting from the obstruction of the meibomian glands.  Unlike hordeolum, chalazion typically presents as a firm, nontender nodule on the eyelid without associated acute inflammation or pain.  It may develop gradually and persist for weeks to months, often requiring warm compresses and sometimes surgical excision for resolution.
  • Eyelid malignancies:  Common malignancies affecting the eyelids include basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and sebaceous gland carcinoma.  Unlike hordeolum, eyelid malignancies often exhibit features such as nonhealing ulcers, nodules, or changes in pigmentation.
  • Dacryocystitis (
    image 3
    ):  An infection or inflammation of the lacrimal sac caused by nasolacrimal duct obstruction that presents with localized swelling, erythema, and tenderness in the medial canthal region.  It is associated with tearing, discharge, and expression of pus from the puncta upon palpation of the lacrimal sac.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Laboratory tests and imaging are typically not required for a diagnosis of hordeolum.  However, in cases of severe or recurrent infections, bacterial cultures or swabs may be obtained to identify the causative organism and guide antibiotic therapy.  Imaging may be indicated in cases of suspected complications such as orbital cellulitis or abscess formation.

Management



Hordeolum is managed conservatively with warm compresses applied to the affected eyelid several times a day to promote glandular drainage and resolution of inflammation.  Lid hygiene measures, such as gentle eyelid cleansing, can help prevent recurrence.



Topical antibiotics are typically not used but may be prescribed in cases of severe or recurrent infections.  Incision and drainage may be necessary for large, fluctuant abscesses or those refractory to conservative measures.

Prognosis



The prognosis for hordeolum is generally favorable, with most cases resolving spontaneously within 1-2 weeks with conservative management.  Recurrence is possible, particularly in patients with underlying skin conditions, but can be minimized with good eyelid hygiene practices.  Complications such as preseptal cellulitis, orbital cellulitis, or eyelid scarring are rare.

Summary



Hordeolum is a common eyelid disorder characterized by localized infection or inflammation of the eyelid glands typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus.  Management is conservative with warm compresses.
